Dr. Upton says the remains are very similar to a type of Aigialosaurus, a subtype of theÂ mesosaur family of marine reptiles that lived during the Cretaceous period. The discovery of this gigantic creature in Bear Lake could finally bring an explanation to almost 150 years ofÂ alleged attacks andÂ sightings in the region. The myth of the â€œBear Lake Monsterâ€ originally grew from articles written in the 19th century by Joseph C. Rich, a Mormon colonizer in the area, purporting to report second-hand accounts of sightings of the creature. In anÂ 1868 article in the Deseret News, heÂ announced that   before goingÂ on to relate several sightings of the creature in recent times. The article created a stir in Salt Lake City and within a month  A 1907 letter published in a Logan, Utah newspaper claimed that two men had seen the Bear Lake behemoth attack their camp and kill one of their horses.Â A 4-year-old alsoÂ claimed toÂ haveÂ seen it in 1937, and a boy scout leader spoke of seeing it in 1946. In recent years the monster was mostly considered to be a tourist attraction, andÂ the last reported sighting of the monster was in June 2002, when Bear Lake business owner, Brian Hirsch, claims to have seen the monster. headline: Memphis, TN | A group of volunteers cleaning up the shores of the Mississippi River near the biggest cityÂ in Tennessee have stumbled upon the remains of an ancient boat encrusted in mud.
description:
A team of archeologists from the University ofÂ Memphis that was rapidly called to the site, confirmed that the ship is most certainly a Viking Knarr, suggesting the Norse would have pushed their exploration of America a lot further than historians previously thought. The heavily damaged ship was found near theÂ confluence of the Wolf and Mississippi rivers and lies on a private property. KnarrsÂ were naval vesselsÂ that were built by theÂ Norsemen from Scandinavia and Iceland for Atlantic voyages but alsoÂ used for trade, commerce, exploration, and warfare during an era known as the Viking Age, that goes approximately from 793 to 1066 AD. They were clinker built, whichÂ means the overlapping of planks riveted together. It was capable of sailing 75 miles (121Â km) in one day and held a crew of about 20 to 30 men. One of the only artifacts on the site, this sword was probably abandoned after it broke, suggesting a violent battle. This new discovery could be one of theÂ oldest evidence of pre-Columbian trans-oceanic contact, and itÂ certainly brings to mindÂ the famous colony ofÂ â€œVinlandâ€ mentioned in the  This mythical colonyÂ would have beenÂ established by Leif Ericson around the same period as the settlementÂ at lâ€™Anse aux Meadows,Â in the Canadian province of Newfoundland and Labrador, the most famous site of a Norse or Viking settlement in North America outside Greenland. TheÂ carbon dating of the newÂ ship estimates that it dates from between 990Â  and 1050 AD, approximately the period associated with Vinland and the various Canadian sites (Lâ€™Anse aux Meadows, TanfieldÂ Valley, Avayalik Islands). Unfortunately,Â very fewÂ other artifacts have yet been found on the site, suggesting the crew must have most likely abandoned the ship and continuedÂ on foot. Professor James Milbury, who leads the research team working on the site, believes the Norse could have been killed by Chickasaw natives. More searches are to be expected in the area over the next few years, as scientists will now certainly try to look for any artifacts or historical traces that could lead them to understand what happened to the crew of the ship. Many myths from local native tribes will also be analyzed by historians from the team to see if they could hold useful information, as both Chickasaw and Choctaw mythologies include many stories of fights against â€œred-haired devilsâ€. headline: Alice Springs | A team of archaeologists working for the Australian National University, who were proceeding to an excavation near the sandstone rock formation of Uluru, has unearthed the ruins of a large pre-colonial city dating back to moreÂ than 1500 years ago.
description:

The images revealed many 90Â° angles and various common geographic figures over a 16 km area, leading the team of scientists to direct some archaeological excavations on the spot, startingÂ in May 2014. Over the last few months, many structures have been unearthed including what looks like a royal palace,Â a fewÂ temples, large rainwater reservoirs, workshopsÂ andÂ dozens ofÂ houses. 287 individual tombs have already been discovered in a small necropolis located just outside the ancient city. Professor Walter Reese, in charge of the site, claims that the extent of the siteÂ and the superposition of various layers of constructions, suggests thatÂ it was occupied for 400 to 500 years, from approximately 470-80 AD,Â up until the 9th Century. He believesÂ that the city could have held between 20000 and 30000 inhabitants, making it the most important center of civilization in the Southern Pacific at the time. TheÂ various artifacts gatheredÂ from the site suggest that the city flourishedÂ thanksÂ to some form of control overÂ various gold mining operations inÂ Southern Australia. The precious metalÂ wasÂ purifiedÂ and transformedÂ by the hundreds of goldsmiths of theÂ city before being traded for various other goods through an extensive network reaching as far as New Zealand, Indonesia, Malaysia, and even China andÂ India. headline: Krosno OdrzaÅ„skie| AÂ pair of Polish fisherman made an amazing discovery when they opened the belly of the 410-pound catfish they had just caught in the Oder river.
description:
The stomach of the monstrous fish contained fragments of human bones, as well as German militaryÂ artifacts dating back to the Second World War. AlfonsÂ BrzozowskiÂ and Marek ZdanowiczÂ were fishing nearÂ the Oderâ€™s confluence with the BÃ³br river on April 6, when theyÂ made an astonishing catch:Â a gigantic Wels catfish, measuring 12 feet (3.68 meters) and weighing 413 pounds (187.5 kg). Their celebration was rapidly transformed into interrogation, and then disgust, when they opened the animalâ€™s belly. Among a large quantity of half-digested fish,Â they discovered an oldÂ metal insigniaÂ dating back toÂ Nazi Germany,Â as wellÂ dozens of human bone fragments. The two fishermen rapidly contacted the police, who opened an investigation to determine the origin of the remains. TheÂ insignia foundÂ in the fishâ€™s belly, turned out to be a German SS hat eagle, dating back to Nazi Germany, that wasÂ usually wornÂ on the front of the SS dress hat. headline: Six employees of a fertility clinic in the city of Lanzhou, in the Northwestern Chinese province of Gansu, received sentences rangingÂ from 8Â  to 25 years in prison after they were found guilty of using pig semen to fertilize dozens of women.
description:

One of these aborted fetusesÂ was so deformedÂ a doctor who saw it demanded an autopsy,Â and it was revealed that the embryo was part human and part animal. They discovered that the clinic was purchasing pig semen from farmers in a nearby village and using it to fertilize its customers. During the investigation of the clinicâ€™s dozens of refrigerated containers, the scientific police discovered over 80 samples of pig semen. The animal semen was labeled was labeled as â€œplatinum qualityâ€ and, surprisingly, sold at a higher price than â€œregular qualityâ€ human semen. Six employees of the clinic were arrested in March and all of them were found guilty yesterdayÂ by the Lanzhou state court. The director of the clinic, Mr. Wong Hu Chan, was sentenced to 25 years of imprisonment for his responsibilityÂ in the fraud. He admitted in his testimony that he had planned this unusual scheme in order to cope with the constant shortages of â€œhigh-quality semenâ€, which is hard to find in China. The clinicâ€™s two doctors were respectively sentenced to 15 years and 20 in prison, while two of the nurses were sentenced to ten years and one to eight years. Four other employees of the clinic had first been suspected, but the investigation showed that they were not aware of the scheme. Mr. Wong Hu Chan, the director of the clinic, was sentenced to 25 years in prison for his role in the crimes. headline: Drogheda | A team of archaeologists affiliated with the University CollegeÂ Dublin, have unearthed three skeletons from a previously unknown humanoid species of extremely small size in aÂ wooded areaÂ of Eastern Ireland.
description:
The specimens measuring between 47 and 61 centimeters are presumably from an entirely new species of humanoid, distinct from modern humans, which would have survived until the 12th or 13th century AD. The bones which wereÂ presumably partially unearthedÂ by a recent rainfall, and were foundÂ by three local children who were playing in the area. The young boysÂ immediately contacted the police, believing they had found the remains of murdered children.Â TheÂ medical examinerÂ called on the site, rapidly understood that this was not a modernÂ crime scene, butÂ seemed instead to beÂ an unusual archeological site. He contacted the University College Dublin to ask for help, and the institution sent Professor Edward JamesÂ McInnes to analyze the discovery. The bodies of two females and one male were discoveredÂ with a small number of artifactsÂ in what appeared to have been a small settlement, near the banks of the river Boyne. The team of archaeologists led by Professor McInnes has named the species  , which means either â€˜  or â€˜ This tiny axe blade was found near the body of the male individual. It is presumed to have been used as both a weapon and a tool. Various small stone Tools and weaponsÂ were found near the bodies, including an axe, two knives, a spear point and even two miniature sewing needles. These items suggest that the Homo Minisculus had only reached a technological level comparable to human hunters-gatherersÂ from the Paleolithic period, as no pottery or metal items have been found on the site. Many bones from various small animals including squirrels, hares, moles, and hedgehogsÂ were found near the settlement, many of which bore traces of cooking. The various dating analyses realized on the bonesÂ and artifacts have shown that they dated from somewhere between 1145 and 1230 AD, which means that the species would have coexisted with modern humans for more than 45000 years. This amazing discovery suggests that many tales and stories from the Middle Ages which were consideredÂ as fantastic by historians could indeedÂ be based onÂ real facts.  could have inspired stories of leprechauns, elves, and browniesÂ that are common in European folklore. Professor McInnes and his team believe that   could have disappeared due to the destruction of its habitat by surrounding human communities. It remains unclear at the moment if Homo Minusculus evolved from Homo erectus, from Homo sapiens idaltu or even from Homo sapiens sapiens, but its morphological similarities with modern humansÂ suggest thatÂ it evolved as a separate subspeciesÂ towards the end of the human lineage. The explanation for its small size also remains a mystery, butÂ Professor McInnes believes it could be linked to the scarcity of resources during the most recent glacial period which extended the last years of the Pleistocene, from approximately 110,000 to 12,000 years ago. After the discovery of the   (that would have stood about 1.1Â m in height) in 2003, on the island of Flores in Indonesia, aÂ human subspeciesÂ which is believed to have gone extinct about 30000 years ago,Â this new find proves that many other hominin subspeciesÂ did indeedÂ coexist with modern humans for thousands of years. headline: A 117-year old man from Texas was liberated from prison this morning after outliving a 99-year sentence, becoming the first prisoner to do so in the history of the United States.
description:
Grandson of one the most famous horse thief in American history, Henry William Borne was arrested by the Texas RangersÂ in 1919 for being part of in an important horse-stealing ring. His father, Henry Borne Jr., was hanged in Fort Worth alongside one of their accomplices, Mark Thompson, on March 16, 1920. headline: â€œ
description:
Astonishingly, the papyri were written by men who participated in the building of the Great Pyramid, the tomb of the Pharaoh Khufu, and mention the use of â€œbeastly creaturesâ€ of â€œenormous sizeâ€ according to Professor Al-Sammud. The outlandish claim would have been rapidlyÂ dismissed if it did not come from one of Egyptologyâ€™s most eminent figures and has definitely come as a surprise to the scientific community. The Narmer Palette, also known as the Great Hierakonpolis Palette or the Palette of Narmer, is a significant Egyptian archeological find, dating from about the 31st century BC, containing some of the earliest hieroglyphic inscriptions ever found and also believed by some to depict living dinosaurs. Surprisingly, the discovery of the ancient papyri and 26 stone cosmetic palettes bearing carved decoration and hieroglyphic writings was made in a nearby cave only a few kilometersÂ outside modern Cairo. The team of researchers believeÂ that the caves had served as a kind of boat storage depot during the fourth dynasty of the Old Kingdom, about 4,600 years ago. â€œWe unearthedÂ entire rolls of papyrus, some a few feet long and still relatively intact, written in hieroglyphics as well as hieratic, the cursive script the ancient Egyptians used for everyday communication,â€ explains phD student Fatima Al-Faya. The papyri also mentionÂ â€œthe noble Ankh-haf,â€ who was known to be the half-brother of the Pharaoh Khufu and is describedÂ as overseeing some of the construction of the Great Pyramid. The most surprising portions of the ancient texts and stone palettes are concerning Ra Nt-Ka, translated as â€œGod beastâ€ which was presumably tamed and used to carry the large limestone blocks that compose the pyramids. â€œFor centuries it was presumed that Ra Nt-Ka was possibly a whale, but here we have descriptionsÂ of Ra Nt-Ka delving in water as well as on land, and the papyri mention that the animal â€œof great statureâ€ was used to carry materials used during theÂ construction of the pyramids,â€ explains Prof Al-Sammud, visibly exhilarated. â€œThey are described as tamed beasts of burden who â€œeat of the Niles grassâ€, whose tail when lashed â€œcan kill an army of menâ€ and â€œwhose necks reach out to the skyâ€, which lets us believe the creature could depictÂ a species of brontosaurus of some kindâ€ he adds. This incredible discovery occurs Â decades after paleontologistsÂ have unearthed the first fossils of a colossal new species of dinosaur in Egypt, one of the heaviest creatures to have walked the Earth. Its name, Paralititan, means tidal giant. The long-necked, long-tailed vegetarian could have straddled a modern African elephant, say experts. â€œWe canâ€™t speculate if this is the species of dinosaur that may have lived amongst ancient Egyptians but fossil remains are fairly prevalent in the Nile region and these amphibious beasts were definitely common in the area at one timeâ€ explains fellow Egyptologist, Helmut Ferrlug of the University of Berlin. One recent skeleton finding in 2014 proved to be a new species of Titanosaurus, a group of long-necked, long-tailed, plant-eating dinosaurs that includes some of the largest animals ever. The period in which Paralititan lived is still a mystery to paleontologists. No no i built the pyramids Your email address will not be published.

headline: Derby | Archaeologists excavating on the site of some recently discovered ruins on the northern coast of Western Australia may have just made the greatest find in the history of the country: the remains an 11th centuryÂ Viking settlement.
description:
The scientists, associated with the Department of Archaeology of the University of Sydney, were called to the site after some locals discovered what looked like the foundation of an ancient building in July, near Derby. The archaeologists, directed by ProfessorÂ Allison Fletcher,Â were expectingÂ a site from the early colonial period, but they rapidly realized that they were dealing with somethingÂ completely different. They have unearthed the foundations of three larger buildings which wereÂ identified as houses, and two smaller workshops identified as a carpentry, which was also used as a boat repair area,Â and a smithy, containing a forge and iron slag. The type of construction and the items found on the site are very similar to the various VikingÂ colonies discovered in Greenland and Iceland. The scientists haveÂ also unearthed a total of sixteen tombs, including these warriors whoÂ were buried with their weapons and treasure. The archaeologists haveÂ discoveredÂ a large quantity and varietyÂ of artifacts on the site, including a few weaponsÂ and blacksmithingÂ tools,Â someÂ bronze and silverÂ jewelry,Â four ivory combs, a few stone oil lamps, a dozenÂ iron rivets and a bone knitting needle. While most of theÂ items seem to be of Norse origin, a few of the items suggest that theÂ inhabitants of the siteÂ were either conductingÂ piracyÂ in the region or they wereÂ part of an extended maritimeÂ trade network. TwoÂ broken pieces ofÂ porcelain, a bronze vesselÂ and a jade ring from ChinaÂ were found in the tomb ofÂ one of theÂ women, andÂ some semi-precious stones from India and Sri Lanka were found in the tomb of one of the warriors. This proves that the Vikings had some form of contacts with the Asian continent, but the nature of these contacts remains uncertain. This large bronze vessel, found in the tomb if a Norse woman of high status, was manufactured in Southeastern China in the 9th or 10th Century. Professor Fletcher believes that the Norsemen could have chosen this siteÂ forÂ its natural harbor, the availability of eucalyptus woodÂ and the regionâ€™s abundant iron ore. Itâ€™s a longÂ distance from the site of any known Viking settlement, expedition or raid, however, and it remains unclear how the Norsemen actually reached Australia. The Vikings were a seafaring people who raided and traded from their Scandinavian homelands across wide areas of northern and central Europe, as well as Russia, during the late 8th to late 11th centuries. UsingÂ their advanced seafaring skills and their famous longships, they are known to have created colonies and trading posts throughout the North Atlantic islands,Â navigating as far as the north-eastern coast of North America. The VikingsÂ are also known to have raided North Africa and some Mediterranean islands, but this is the first time that any trace of their presence is found in the Indian Ocean. headline: Savannah, GA | AÂ couple of tourists from Canada made a surprising discovery while scuba diving in Wassaw Sound, a small bay locatedÂ on the shores of Georgia.
description:
Jason Sutter and Christina MurrayÂ were admiring the marine lifeÂ of the area when they stumbled upon a Mark 15 thermonuclear bomb that had been lost by theÂ United StatesÂ Air Force more than 50 years ago. The couple from London in Ontario,Â was onÂ a two-week vacation in Georgia and Florida to practice their favorite hobby, scuba diving when they decided to dive near the shores of Tybee Island. While admiring the plants and fishes near the sea floor, they noticed a large cylindrical itemÂ partially covered by sand. They investigated the object andÂ found outÂ that it was actually a sort of bomb or missile, so they decided to contact the authorities. The couple is still shocked after their frightening discovery and say they will avoid diving for the rest of their trip. Rapidly understanding the gravity of the situation, the 911 operator contacted every possible emergency service, including the coast guard and the military,Â leading to theÂ deployment of more than 20 ships and 1500 men in the area. Using theÂ GPS coordinatesÂ given by the couple, they rapidly located the powerful 3.8 megaton bomb. An unmanned submarine was sent to determine the condition of the bomb before explosive experts were sent to disarm it. Fortunately, the thermonuclear weaponÂ produced in 1955 seemedÂ inÂ sufficiently good shapeÂ for a team of Navy seals toÂ tryÂ toÂ defuse it. They successfully deactivated theÂ warhead after hours of strenuous work, allowing the rest of the bomb to be moved. Navy explosive ordnance Disposal technicians spent nearly five hours working on the warhead beforeÂ they were able to extract the detonator and the uranium coreÂ of the weapon, allowing the fuselageÂ to beÂ moved. The federal and state authorities were well-aware that a nuclearÂ warheadÂ had been lost in the area in the 1950â€™s and had never been recovered, but no efforts had been done for years to recover it. ItÂ was lostÂ on the night of February 5, 1958, whenÂ a B-47 Stratojet bomber carryingÂ the 7,600-poundÂ hydrogen bomb on aÂ  simulated combat mission off the coast of Georgia collided with an F-86 Saberjet fighter at 36,000 feet of altitude. The collision destroyed the fighter and severely damaged a wing of the bomber, leaving one of its engines partially dislodged. The bomberâ€™s pilot, Maj. Howard Richardson was instructed by the Homestead Air Force Base in Florida.Â to jettison the H-bomb before attempting a landing. Richardson dropped the bomb into the shallow waters of Wassaw Sound, near the mouth of the Savannah River, where he believed the bomb would be swiftly recovered. The crew did not see an explosion when the bomb struck the sea andÂ they managed to land the B-47 safely at the nearest base. For the following six weeks, the Air Force looked for the bomb without success. Underwater divers scoured the depths, troops tromped through nearby salt marshes, and a blimp hovered over the area attempting to spot a hole or crater in the beach or swamp. Researches were finally abandoned and the bomb remained hidden for more than 50 years until the unlucky couple stumbled upon it.
